name: cloudfunctions
title: Google Cloud Functions API
description: API for managing lightweight user-provided functions executed in response to events.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.desc: Selector specifying which fields to include in a partial response.

parameters.name: quotaUser
parameters.desc: Available to use for quota purposes for server-side applications. Can be any arbitrary string assigned to a user, but should not exceed 40 characters.

parameters.name: oauth_token
parameters.desc: OAuth 2.0 token for the current user.

parameters.name: key
parameters.desc: API key. Your API key identifies your project and provides you with API access, quota, and reports. Required unless you provide an OAuth 2.0 token.

parameters.name: prettyPrint
parameters.desc: Returns response with indentations and line breaks.

schemas.name: Status
schemas.desc:
The `Status` type defines a logical error model that is suitable for different
programming environments, including REST APIs and RPC APIs. It is used by
[gRPC](https://github.com/grpc). The error model is designed to be:

- Simple to use and understand for most users
- Flexible enough to meet unexpected needs

# Overview

The `Status` message contains three pieces of data: error code, error message,
and error details. The error code should be an enum value of
google.rpc.Code, but it may accept additional error codes if needed.  The
error message should be a developer-facing English message that helps
developers *understand* and *resolve* the error. If a localized user-facing
error message is needed, put the localized message in the error details or
localize it in the client. The optional error details may contain arbitrary
information about the error. There is a predefined set of error detail types
in the package `google.rpc` which can be used for common error conditions.

# Language mapping

The `Status` message is the logical representation of the error model, but it
is not necessarily the actual wire format. When the `Status` message is
exposed in different client libraries and different wire protocols, it can be
mapped differently. For example, it will likely be mapped to some exceptions
in Java, but more likely mapped to some error codes in C.

# Other uses

The error model and the `Status` message can be used in a variety of
environments, either with or without APIs, to provide a
consistent developer experience across different environments.

Example uses of this error model include:

- Partial errors. If a service needs to return partial errors to the client,
    it may embed the `Status` in the normal response to indicate the partial
    errors.

- Workflow errors. A typical workflow has multiple steps. Each step may
    have a `Status` message for error reporting purpose.

- Batch operations. If a client uses batch request and batch response, the
    `Status` message should be used directly inside batch response, one for
    each error sub-response.

- Asynchronous operations. If an API call embeds asynchronous operation
    results in its response, the status of those operations should be
    represented directly using the `Status` message.

- Logging. If some API errors are stored in logs, the message `Status` could
    be used directly after any stripping needed for security/privacy reasons.

fields.name: code
fields.desc: The status code, which should be an enum value of google.rpc.Code.

fields.name: message
fields.desc:
A developer-facing error message, which should be in English. Any
user-facing error message should be localized and sent in the
google.rpc.Status.details field, or localized by the client.

fields.name: details
fields.desc:
A list of messages that carry the error details.  There will be a
common set of message types for APIs to use.

schemas.name: SourceRepository
schemas.desc: Describes the location of the function source in a remote repository.

fields.name: revision
fields.desc:
The id of the revision that captures the state of the repository from
which the function should be fetched.

fields.name: repositoryUrl
fields.desc:
URL to the hosted repository where the function is defined. Only paths in
https://source.developers.google.com domain are supported. The path should
contain the name of the repository.

fields.name: tag
fields.desc:
The name of the tag that captures the state of the repository from
which the function should be fetched.

fields.name: branch
fields.desc: The name of the branch from which the function should be fetched.

fields.name: deployedRevision
fields.desc:
Output only. The id of the revision that was resolved at the moment of
function creation or update. For example when a user deployed from a
branch, it will be the revision id of the latest change on this branch at
that time. If user deployed from revision then this value will be always
equal to the revision specified by the user.

fields.name: sourcePath
fields.desc:
The path within the repository where the function is defined. The path
should point to the directory where Cloud Functions files are located. Use
"/" if the function is defined directly in the root directory of a
repository.

fields.name: functions
fields.desc: The functions that match the request.

fields.name: nextPageToken
fields.desc:
If not empty, indicates that there may be more functions that match
the request; this value should be passed in a new
google.cloud.functions.v1beta2.ListFunctionsRequest
to get more functions.

fields.name: executionId
fields.desc: Execution id of function invocation.

fields.name: result
fields.desc:
Result populated for successful execution of synchronous function. Will
not be populated if function does not return a result through context.

fields.name: error
fields.desc:
Either system or user-function generated error. Set if execution
was not successful.

schemas.name: EventTrigger
schemas.desc:
Describes EventTrigger, used to request events be sent from another
service.

fields.name: resource
fields.desc:
Which instance of the source's service should send events. E.g. for Pub/Sub
this would be a Pub/Sub topic at `projects/*/topics/*`. For Google Cloud
Storage this would be a bucket at `projects/*/buckets/*`. For any source
that only supports one instance per-project, this should be the name of the
project (`projects/*`)

fields.name: eventType
fields.desc:
`event_type` names contain the service that is sending an event and the
kind of event that was fired. Must be of the form
`providers/*/eventTypes/*` e.g. Directly handle a Message published to
Google Cloud Pub/Sub `providers/cloud.pubsub/eventTypes/topic.publish`

     Handle an object changing in Google Cloud Storage
     `providers/cloud.storage/eventTypes/object.change`

     Handle a write to the Firebase Realtime Database
     `providers/firebase.database/eventTypes/data.write`

schemas.name: HTTPSTrigger
schemas.desc: Describes HTTPSTrigger, could be used to connect web hooks to function.

fields.name: url
fields.desc: Output only. The deployed url for the function.

schemas.name: Operation
schemas.desc:
This resource represents a long-running operation that is the result of a
network API call.

fields.name: name
fields.desc:
The server-assigned name, which is only unique within the same service that
originally returns it. If you use the default HTTP mapping, the
`name` should have the format of `operations/some/unique/name`.

fields.name: error
fields.desc: The error result of the operation in case of failure or cancellation.

fields.name: metadata
fields.desc:
Service-specific metadata associated with the operation.  It typically
contains progress information and common metadata such as create time.
Some services might not provide such metadata.  Any method that returns a
long-running operation should document the metadata type, if any.

fields.name: done
fields.desc:
If the value is `false`, it means the operation is still in progress.
If true, the operation is completed, and either `error` or `response` is
available.

fields.name: response
fields.desc:
The normal response of the operation in case of success.  If the original
method returns no data on success, such as `Delete`, the response is
`google.protobuf.Empty`.  If the original method is standard
`Get`/`Create`/`Update`, the response should be the resource.  For other
methods, the response should have the type `XxxResponse`, where `Xxx`
is the original method name.  For example, if the original method name
is `TakeSnapshot()`, the inferred response type is
`TakeSnapshotResponse`.

fields.name: target
fields.desc:
Target of the operation - for example
projects/project-1/locations/region-1/functions/function-1

fields.name: request
fields.desc: The original request that started the operation.

fields.name: type
fields.desc: Type of operation.

fields.name: data
fields.desc: Input to be passed to the function.

schemas.name: CloudFunction
schemas.desc:
Describes a Cloud Function that contains user computation executed in
response to an event. It encapsulate function and triggers configurations.

fields.name: updateTime
fields.desc: Output only. The last update timestamp of a Cloud Function.

fields.name: eventTrigger
fields.desc: A source that fires events in response to a condition in another service.

fields.name: status
fields.desc: Output only. Status of the function deployment.

enum.name: FAILED
enum.desc:
Not deployed correctly - behavior is undefined. The item should be updated
or deleted to move it out of this state.

fields.name: serviceAccount
fields.desc: Output only. The service account of the function.

fields.name: sourceArchiveUrl
fields.desc:
The URL, starting with gs://, pointing to the zip archive which contains
the function.

fields.name: entryPoint
fields.desc:
The name of the function (as defined in source code) that will be
executed. Defaults to the resource name suffix, if not specified. For
backward compatibility, if function with given name is not found, then the
system will try to use function named "function".
For Node.js this is name of a function exported by the module specified
in `source_location`.

fields.name: latestOperation
fields.desc:
Output only. Name of the most recent operation modifying the function. If
the function status is `DEPLOYING` or `DELETING`, then it points to the
active operation.

fields.name: httpsTrigger
fields.desc: An HTTPS endpoint type of source that can be triggered via URL.

fields.name: timeout
fields.desc:
The function execution timeout. Execution is considered failed and
can be terminated if the function is not completed at the end of the
timeout period. Defaults to 60 seconds.

fields.name: availableMemoryMb
fields.desc:
The amount of memory in MB available for a function.
Defaults to 256MB.

fields.name: name
fields.desc:
A user-defined name of the function. Function names must be unique
globally and match pattern `projects/*/locations/*/functions/*`

fields.name: sourceRepository
fields.desc: The hosted repository where the function is defined.

schemas.name: Location
schemas.desc: A resource that represents Google Cloud Platform location.

fields.name: locationId
fields.desc: The canonical id for this location. For example: `"us-east1"`.

fields.name: metadata
fields.desc:
Service-specific metadata. For example the available capacity at the given
location.

fields.name: labels
fields.desc:
Cross-service attributes for the location. For example

    {"cloud.googleapis.com/region": "us-east1"}

fields.name: name
fields.desc:
Resource name for the location, which may vary between implementations.
For example: `"projects/example-project/locations/us-east1"`

fields.name: operations
fields.desc: A list of operations that matches the specified filter in the request.

fields.name: nextPageToken
fields.desc: The standard List next-page token.

fields.name: locations
fields.desc: A list of locations that matches the specified filter in the request.

fields.name: nextPageToken
fields.desc: The standard List next-page token.

methods.name: list
methods.desc: Lists information about the supported locations for this service.

pathParams.name: name
pathParams.desc: The resource that owns the locations collection, if applicable.

methods.name: get
methods.desc: Returns a function with the given name from the requested project.

pathParams.name: name
pathParams.desc: The name of the function which details should be obtained.

pathParams.name: name
pathParams.desc: The name of the function to be updated.

methods.name: delete
methods.desc:
Deletes a function with the given name from the specified project. If the
given function is used by some trigger, the trigger will be updated to
remove this function.

pathParams.name: name
pathParams.desc: The name of the function which should be deleted.

methods.name: list
methods.desc: Returns a list of functions that belong to the requested project.

pathParams.name: location
pathParams.desc:
The project and location from which the function should be listed,
specified in the format `projects/*/locations/*`
If you want to list functions in all locations, use "-" in place of a
location.

optinalQueryParams.name: pageToken
optinalQueryParams.desc:
The value returned by the last
`ListFunctionsResponse`; indicates that
this is a continuation of a prior `ListFunctions` call, and that the
system should return the next page of data.

optinalQueryParams.name: pageSize
optinalQueryParams.desc: Maximum number of functions to return per call.

methods.name: create
methods.desc:
Creates a new function. If a function with the given name already exists in
the specified project, the long running operation will return
`ALREADY_EXISTS` error.

pathParams.name: location
pathParams.desc:
The project and location in which the function should be created, specified
in the format `projects/*/locations/*`

methods.name: call
methods.desc:
Invokes synchronously deployed function. To be used for testing, very
limited traffic allowed.

pathParams.name: name
pathParams.desc: The name of the function to be called.

methods.name: list
methods.desc:
Lists operations that match the specified filter in the request. If the
server doesn't support this method, it returns `UNIMPLEMENTED`.

NOTE: the `name` binding below allows API services to override the binding
to use different resource name schemes, such as `users/*/operations`.

optinalQueryParams.name: name
optinalQueryParams.desc: The name of the operation collection.

methods.name: get
methods.desc:
Gets the latest state of a long-running operation.  Clients can use this
method to poll the operation result at intervals as recommended by the API
service.

pathParams.name: name
pathParams.desc: The name of the operation resource.
